abstract.text: Configure input devices, output media, preview views, and basic settings before capturing photos or video.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: An

is the basis for all media capture in iOS and macOS. It manages your app’s exclusive access to the OS capture infrastructure and capture devices, as well as the flow of data from input devices to media outputs. How you configure connections between inputs and outputs defines the capabilities of your capture session. For example, the diagram below shows a capture session that can capture both photos and movies and provides a camera preview, using the iPhone back camera and microphone.

content.text: Connect Inputs and Outputs to the Session

inlineContent.text: All capture sessions need at least one capture input and capture output. Capture inputs (
subclasses) are media sources—typically recording devices like the cameras and microphone built into an iOS device or Mac. Capture outputs (
subclasses) use data provided by capture inputs to produce media, like image and movie files.
To use a camera for video input (to capture photos or movies), select an appropriate
, create a corresponding
, and add it to the session:
iOS offers several other ways to select a camera device. For more information, see
Next, add outputs for the kinds of media you plan to capture from the camera you’ve selected. For example, to enable capturing photos, add an
to the session:
A session can have multiple inputs and outputs. For example:
To record both video and audio in a movie, add inputs for both camera and microphone devices.
To capture both photos and movies from the same camera, add both
and
to your session.
Call
before changing a session’s inputs or outputs, and call
after making changes.

It’s important to let the user see input from the camera before choosing to snap a photo or start video recording, as in the viewfinder of a traditional camera. You can provide such a preview by connecting an
to your capture session, which displays a live video feed from the camera whenever the session is running.
is a Core Animation layer, so you can display and style it in your interface as you would any other
subclass. The simplest way to add a preview layer to a UIKit app is to define a
subclass whose
is
, as shown below.

code: /// Convenience wrapper to get layer as its statically known type.

inlineContent.text: Then, to use the preview layer with a capture session, set the layer’s
property:
If your app supports multiple interface orientations, use the preview layer’s
to the capture session to set a
matching that of your UI.
After you’ve configured inputs, outputs, and previews, call
to let data flow from inputs to outputs.
With some capture outputs, running the session is all you need to begin media capture. For example, if your session contains an
, you start receiving delivering video frames as soon as the session is running.

With other capture outputs, you first start the session running, then use the capture output class itself to initiate capture. In a photography app, for example, running the session enables a viewfinder-style preview, but you use the
method to snap a picture.

abstract.text: Work with audiovisual assets, control device cameras, process audio, and configure system audio interactions.
An object that represents a connection from a capture input to a capture output.
An orientation that tells the connection how to rotate a video flowing through it.
An object that represents a hardware or virtual capture device like a camera or microphone.
An object that provides media input from a capture device to a capture session.
An abstract superclass for objects that provide input data to a capture session.
A capture output that records video and audio to a QuickTime movie file.
A capture session that supports simultaneous capture from multiple inputs of the same media type.
An abstract superclass for objects that provide media output destinations for a capture session.
A capture output for still image, Live Photos, and other photography workflows.
Initiates a photo capture using the specified settings.
An object that configures capture behavior and coordinates the flow of data from input devices to capture outputs.
Marks the beginning of changes to a running capture session’s configuration to perform in a single atomic update.
Commits one or more changes to a running capture session’s configuration in a single atomic update.
Starts the flow of data through the capture pipeline.
A capture output that records video and provides access to video frames for processing.
A Core Animation layer that displays video from a camera device.
An object that describes the connection from the layer to a particular input port.
A capture session with visual output to preview.
Capture photos and record video using the front and rear iPhone and iPad cameras.
Identify machine readable codes or faces by using the camera.
Simultaneously record the output from the front and back cameras into a single movie file by using a multi-camera capture session.
Configure built-in cameras and microphones, and external capture devices, for media capture.
Select the front or back camera, or use advanced features like the TrueDepth camera or dual camera.
Operate the camera in Split View, Slide Over, Picture in Picture, and Stage Manager modes.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Accessing the camera while multitasking on iPad

abstract.text: An object that manages image-based content and allows you to perform animations on that content.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Returns the class used to create the layer for instances of this class.
